properties.description:
Parametric Curve
Once a function is defined, we can re-use it for different purposes. Here, we draw a curve.

Point
And here we animate a point. Note that "T" is the slider value.

properties.name: f\left(t\right)
properties.description:
Function
Functions can be scalar-valued or vector-valued. Here's a vector-valued function.

Explicit Surface:
We can use the slider variables defined above in defining a surface (or any expression)

title: Surface of Revolution: Washer Method (Horizontal Axis)

properties.description:
Vector:
By default, vectors have their tails at the origin

Vector:
A different tail can be specified in object settings. Open object settings by pressing the gear.

Vector:
The tail can  position can contain variables  or functions.
Here the tail has coordinates [X,-2,-1]

Explicit Surface (Polar)
Press the colored dot next to a graphics object to toggle visibility; press and hold to change color.

properties.name: df(t)
properties.description:
Function:
"diff" is an operator that differentiates functions using the syntax below.
In general, "diff" returns the total derivative and may be scalar-valued, vector-valued, or matrix-valued.

title: The TNB Vectors for Parametric Curves

properties.description:
Parametric Surface:
This sphere uses g(u - T, v) as its color map.
Hold-press the rainbow, then switch to "Color Map" for details.

Parametric Curve
Sliders can be used to animate the plot range for curves and surfaces.

properties.name: T
properties.description:
Variable Slider
Slider endpoints can contain symbols like pi, or other even variables.

title: Using Sliders to Animate Plot Range

properties.description:
Point:
Open object settings (press the gear) to add a label to a point. Make sure to also set "labelVisible".
properties.label: My Point

properties.description:
Vector
Vectors and lines can be labeled, too. Vector and line labels appear at the end.
properties.label: Your Vector

properties.description: Osculating Circle: u is the point of tangency, t is the parameter

properties.name: f(x)
properties.description:
Here x is crit chance, y is raw AD, and damage 
in the z axis.

Camera
While the camera position is animated, rotate, zoom, and pan are automatically turned off.

properties.name: f(t)
properties.description:
Function:
This function and the slider above are used to animate the camera position. Activate the "Axes & Camera" tab above to see how.

properties.name: f\left(u,\ t\right)
properties.description: Osculating Circle: u is the point of tangency, t is the parameter

ParametricCurve
This red curve is hard to see because it has the same 3D-position as the blue surface. The renderer can't decide which object to draw on top.

Parametric Curve
Setting the z-bias in object settings (click the gear) is a nice way to solve this problem. Try viewing the yellow line from different angle: it will always appear closer to the camera.
The z-bias of an object is a positional bias toward the camera ("z" in the context refers to an axis pointing toward the camera, not the mathematical z axis.)

Explicit Surface (Polar)
To control visibility with a toggle, set the value of "calculated visibility" in object settings (press the gear).

properties.name: dragon
properties.description:
Toggle Switch:
A toggle switch is a boolean variable (true/false). Toggles can be used to control the  visibility of multiple graphics objects at once.

This toggle has the silly name "dragon".

title: Controlling Multiple Object Visibility with Toggles

properties.expr: _f(t)=\left[U\cdot t+a,\ V\cdot t+b,\ f\left(U\cdot t+a,V\cdot t+b\right)\right]
_f(t)=\left[U\cdot t+a,\ V\cdot t+b,\ f\left(a,b\right)+f_x\left(a,b\right)\cdot U\cdot t+f_y\left(a,b\right)\cdot V\cdot t\right]

title: Distancia de un punto a una recta
